    Motorhome Power Setup

    Understand your 12V system, stay charged, and travel further

    Motorhome Power Setup

    How to power your motorhome ‚Äî from hook-ups to solar and off-grid systems.

    üîå The Basics: 12V vs. 230V

    • 12V system ‚Äì Powers lights, water pump, USB ports, fridge (on gas/12V), and some fans.
    • 230V mains (hook-up) ‚Äì Powers sockets, microwave, kettle, and charges your leisure battery.
    • Inverter ‚Äì Converts 12V battery power to 230V for short-term use (e.g., laptop, camera).

    üí° Tip: Don‚Äôt run high-wattage appliances (like kettles or hairdryers) off your inverter unless it‚Äôs rated for it.

    üîã Leisure Battery

    • What it does ‚Äì Stores power for your 12V system when not on hook-up.
    • Types ‚Äì Lead-acid, AGM, or lithium (more expensive but lighter and longer-lasting).
    • Capacity ‚Äì Measured in amp-hours (Ah). 100Ah is a common starting point.
    • Charging methods:
      • Hook-up (via onboard charger)
      • Solar panel
      • Engine alternator (while driving)
      • Generator (less common, noisy)

    ‚òÄÔ∏è Solar Power

    • Why it‚Äôs great ‚Äì Keeps your battery topped up off-grid.
    • Fixed vs. portable:
      • Fixed panels ‚Äì Roof-mounted, always charging when sunny.
      • Portable panels ‚Äì Can be angled, moved with the sun, stored when not in use.
    • Controller ‚Äì MPPT is more efficient than PWM.
    • Size guide:
      • 100W = light use (lights, USB)
      • 200W+ = moderate off-grid use
      • 300W+ = extended off-grid, fridge, laptops, etc.

    ‚ö° Inverters

    • Pure sine wave ‚Äì Best for sensitive electronics (laptops, CPAP machines).
    • Modified sine wave ‚Äì Cheaper, but not ideal for all devices.
    • Size matters ‚Äì Match inverter wattage to your highest-draw device (e.g., 300W for a laptop, 1000W+ for a kettle).

    üîå Hook-Up Tips

    • Use a 25m cable ‚Äì Some pitches are awkwardly placed.
    • Check polarity ‚Äì Especially in Europe; use a tester plug.
    • Don‚Äôt overload ‚Äì Most sites offer 6A‚Äì16A. Avoid running multiple high-wattage devices at once.
    • Use a surge protector ‚Äì Protects your gear from dodgy site electrics.

    üß™ Monitor & Manage

    • Battery monitor ‚Äì Shows voltage, amps, and charge level.
    • Smart chargers ‚Äì Maintain battery health when on hook-up.
    • Power audit ‚Äì Know what each device draws and how long you use it.

    üß≠ Off-Grid Readiness Checklist

    • 100Ah+ leisure battery
    • Solar panel (fixed or portable)
    • Inverter (pure sine wave if using laptops)
    • LED lighting (low draw)
    • USB charging hub
    • Efficient fridge (3-way or compressor)
    • Water tank full, waste tank empty
    • Apps for finding wild spots (Park4Night, Searchforsites)
